page.title: 19The Village of Gayles
page.content: Gayles, derived from the Celtic name Gallia "ia" - a land or territory and "gall" - a stranger, is divided into three separate streets; Middle, East & West. In between each street is a substantial open area, although the original form has been changed in recent years by the small modern development of stone built bungalows and houses. East Street is much as it was in the 19th century. The Bay Horse public house is the only facility in the village, although a regular bus service operates Monday to Saturday between Richmond and Barnard Castle. The working population are employed in agriculture,local government,the Civil Service or transport and utilities. Owing to its isolated position, it is unlikely that this small village will be permitted to enlarge its boundaries in the future.
